reviewText: Would you believe that Jack Arnold directed this movie? The same person that directed "Creature From the Black Lagoon" (1954).One look at the cast and you can tell that this is going to be a great movie. Most of the cast shows up in John Wayne movies.  And maybe Road movies.  And the music is Henry Mancini. You also get a nice view of the high desert in southern California.A.J Niles writes risqué books about how Europeans live. Now due to a tax mix-up he must return to the US. His publisher subsidizes his new research on how the Americans live. He does this research incognito as Jack Adams the only bachelor in a housing development named "Paradise Valley."Looks like trouble is stirring in Paradise.
summary: Now there is a man with an arrested development.

reviewText: From the stylish cartoon opening with the peppy Mancini Song, you know you're in for a fluffy treat.The sets are wonderful (particularly if you are a fan of Mid-Century Modern, as I am) the dialog is sparkling, the characters are fun and the movie doesn't overstay its welcome. The plot stays true to Bob Hope movie formulas, so you know what's going to happen, but there are plenty of wacky hijinks along the way (the oversudsing washing machine, the trip to the supermarket) to divert you.All in all, it's a fun trip back to a time when movie people could get drunk without the audience getting beat over the head with a moral message, and movie kids were just kids, without having to be either overly cutesy or annoyingly smartass.  Definitely an asset to anyone's movie collection.
summary: Pecky Cypress - it's all the rage!
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is a cute and not too serious movie from 1961 starring Bob Hope and Lana Turner in a lighthearted romantic comedy. But what I really enjoyed was the clothes, interiors, and hairstyles from the late 1950's. And the cars with giant tailfins! Worth watching for those wonderful styles of a bygone era, which I remember well from my high school years. Bob's little hat. His narrow ties. The big skirts women wore.Lana Turner's hair is so structured, coifed and cemented it's amazing she was able to hold her head up. And the sex stuff - so mild and sweet by today's standards. Cute movie, the America of a more innocent time.
summary: Tailfins, hairstyles, big dresses and small ties

reviewText: BACHELOR IN PARADISE (1962, 111 minutes) is a strange film, half comedy, half life-study. It is also simply not that funny. Bob Hope, such a genius as recently as in THE IRON PETTICOAT (1956), is used here as a cardboard cutout figure, frequently at the center of silly gags while cracking almost no jokes.The story is brief: Hope plays a lecherous author who has published over a dozen books about how to seduce women in various countries. The books are typical of the 1960s trash I recall, posing as books of scholarly merit while being nothing but goofy, smutty tales.After some legal hassles and losing his fortune, Hope is sent into a "tract housing" development to cool his heels. His publisher/agent is also looking for Hope to write a book based on the American woman's needs. He finds himself hip-deep in southern California tract neighborhood intrigue - and staring down the throat of Lana Turner.Well, this tired old thing is so tedious that I often just switch it off, wondering why I ever even bother to watch it. Mainly I like the cars (WAY too few) and seeing the California neighborhoods, with which I am familiar, when they were first being built. It also reminds me of the deep impact these kinds of stupid films had on stupid TV sitcoms in the late 1960s and especially in the 1970s.What you won't get here is any kind of warmth or real humor from Hope, who had taken to grumpy, totally non-humorous roles around this time. This film is also misogynistic in the extreme, but then that's the way it was back then.Save your pennies for either PETTICOAT or even a few of the original "ROAD" movies Hope did with Bing Crosby.

reviewText: If you're looking for a clean, funny, classic movie, this is it.  Bob Hope is great as a writer, hiding out in a California housing tract and helping the women of the neighborhood spice up their marriages, while gathering material for his book on American marriages.  With Paula Prentiss, Jim Hutton, Lana Turner and other great actors, you're in for a lot of laughs.  Remember, this is a 1961 movie.  It's worth seeing for the fashions and what the California hills looked like before they were all filled with houses.  Enjoy!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Here is a case of another surprise sprung on an unsuspecting viewer of TCM-Africa. A writer (Bob Hope) is trapped into writing a book on How American's Live, to pay back-taxes. He is transported from the East Coast to the West; to be integrated in Paradise (Village, in the San Fernando Valley of California). It is a modern planned community, where everything is in its place, including the parents and two children in each household, the husbands' daily commute and the wives' tending home as is their place in life, according to that time (the early 1960s, when men were still wearing hats). It had all the hallmarks of a suburban idyll (not Radburn or the principles enshrined in Alexander's Community and Privacy - for dedicated town planners), captured in the roles defined by convention. The counterpart to a very funny Bob Hope (with some terrific `one-liners') is a stunning and very surprising Lana Turner. The comedy proceeds apace as he awakens the wives to the notion that they should expect more in marriage and indeed, in life. While the film is a gentle comedy (which reveals the early comedic potential of Paula Prentice), it has a serious point to make, certainly on archaic thinking about women but maybe even, on suburbia itself!Ian Hunter.Author of `e-Love'.
summary: A gentle comedy with a serious point

reviewText: I love so many movies there is no way I could choose just one, however, this one is up there.  It's not something that a lot of people would like in this day and age with "stay at home mums", "husbands who believe a wife's place is in the home" and other such ridiculous ideas, but, Bob Hope's character's comedic take on the whole situation makes it all the more fun.  I thoroughly recommend this to anyone of the over 40's who could appreciate it as I do.

reviewText: Being a huge fan of Bob Hope, I knew that the movies produced later in his career were not nearly as sharp or funny as his earlier work. I actually hold the writers and directors responsible, because his stage performances (i.e. His work for the USO and Christmas specials throughout the same period) proves the man was *extraordinarily* hilarious throughout his entire lifetime. The material and the framework is what hobbled his latter films.This is another example of that. It's too tame, too choreographed, and too flat. It's a PG rated movie that needs a wink toward PG-13 and a nudge toward an R.Bob's biggest and best often included his constant not-so-subtle fumbling attempts to bed his co-star. And while Bachelor does include that as part of the plot - it's soooo timid. It's like the Hays Commission was literally on set watching every move and checkmarking down every word. And that severely weakened what could've been a much more fun film. A movie that literally begged for a touch of the 'real' Bob Hope.Decidedly for hardcore fans of the man only.Please note that this film is now (November 2010) downloadable in widescreen format.

reviewText: Even though this movie is a little dated, it's still really funny.  I always liked this movie when it was on TV in the past, but I wasn't sure if I would still like it due to not seeing it for so long.  I ended up loving this movie.  Bob Hope's one liners & facial expressions are priceless.  Bob plays a writer that must do research on the lives of couples living in the suburbs for a book in order to get money to pay off the IRS.  Overall, it's a fun filled movie that's great to watch over & over again!

reviewText: As much as I like Bob Hope, I didn't care for his role here. Instead of his self-deprecating persona, we get a slightly snarky, slightly d*kish playboy Hope who somehow gains a conscience when he moves into the suburbs.Mid-century buffs, be sure to look for--Proto-siitcom gags: the nosy neighbor, the too-much-soap-in-the-washer bitCultural anomalies: a girl left alone in the car while mom shops; sprinklers on in the afternoonFabulous mid-century style: a coral  pink house in newly-planted suburbs; a two-tone bar and closets; linoleum tile samples; cocktails and heels in the morning
summary: Come for Hope, stay for the cocktails

reviewText: This is another of Bob Hopes fun films !  Lana Turner plays hard to get in this wonderful movie.  Warner states on the case that it is remastered;  however it is not up to what I would call remastered though.  There is nice color balance;  but a lot of dirt and scratches that are normally not in a remaster.  There is one scene in the movie with Hope in the kitchen trying to get a garbage disposal freed up when all of a sudden the color changes hue and is somewhat saturated.  This is only for a short time period.  It was really great to see this movie come out on DVD;  but the quality represents that of a VHS version.  If you like Bob Hope- you wont be too disappointed.  Just wish that Warner Brothers would have taken time to give this movie proper treatment.
summary: Bob Hope in another great Classic !!!
